CONTEMPORARY COMMENT

Armament Leads To War
connection with .the .Adraiuet*stion drive for a
bigger and better navy, Representative Taylor recently
said: "I feel that with England branching out on a
$7,500,000,000 increase and with the Old World going
crazy, we would be stupid not to take adequate precautions."
Representative Taylor's statement is typical of the
Armament demands now booming on every side. The
world is going crazy, and we've got to go crazy too.
Sometimes, in the feverish heat of an arms race, it
is difficult to stop and examine this doctrine. It is hard
to discover who began this madness, this insane competition. Locating the specific government that was the
first to announce a new navy-building program will not
solve the issue. We must trace the problem back further, find that that country was motivated by the fear
that its neighbor would "beat it to the draw," and finally realize that the blame for world rearmament rests
upon every land that has indulged in hatreds, suspicions, jealousies, and chauvinistic insolence. America
is not free from this charge.
. Armaments are one of the leading causes of war,
and the President's demand is a step along that road.
Instead of such a policy, our State Department would
do well to take a more common sensical direction toward the same goal. By aligning ourselves in a solid
front with our sister democracies against the predatory
states, by working slowly toward all possible disarmament, and by agitating for government control of
munitions, our statesmen would better further the cause
of peace.
Any immediate disarmament would be too drastic a
step. However, we should refuse any increase in arms
as the only way to eventual peace. We must resist the
pressure of war hysteria, the schernings of the gun
peddlers, and the intimidations of the vested interests.
We must stand by mankind's frail dream of peace!

The Johns Hopkins Musical Club,
the oldest of the Campus Activities.
was first organized as a Glee Club in
1833. With the growth of the University enrollment, the Musical Club has
remained the largest extra-curricula:
activity; its membership is now approximately one hundred men, embracing the Glee Club, the Banjo
Club, the Hawaiian Troupe and the
Blue Jay Orchestra, as well as smaller groups and soloiets.

Ingham Of News-Letter Is
Official Representative
— •
Giver 1200 amateur journalists
were drawn to New York City from
Eastern colleges and institutions for
the New York Times Christmas Conference on December 28. John Higham, '41, reporter and editorial writer
for the NEWS-LETTER, was official
Hopkins representative.
The Conference, an all-day affair
held in the Hotel Biltmore, featured
speakers on newspaper work and international affairs. In the morning
eleven editors, feature writers, and
executives of the Times addressed the
gathering on aspects of practical
journalism.
The afternoon was devoted to in,.etiational relations. Dr. Charles G.
Fe nwick, Professor
of Political
Science at Bryn Mawr College, spoke
on 'Neutrality and International
Responsibility". Dr. Fenwick received his Ph. D. at Hopkins.
The conference was concluded with
a trip through the Times plant in the
evening.

CONTEMPORARY COMMENT

Armament Leads To War
connection with .the .Adraiuet*stion drive for a
bigger and better navy, Representative Taylor recently
said: "I feel that with England branching out on a
$7,500,000,000 increase and with the Old World going
crazy, we would be stupid not to take adequate precautions."
Representative Taylor's statement is typical of the
Armament demands now booming on every side. The
world is going crazy, and we've got to go crazy too.
Sometimes, in the feverish heat of an arms race, it
is difficult to stop and examine this doctrine. It is hard
to discover who began this madness, this insane competition. Locating the specific government that was the
first to announce a new navy-building program will not
solve the issue. We must trace the problem back further, find that that country was motivated by the fear
that its neighbor would "beat it to the draw," and finally realize that the blame for world rearmament rests
upon every land that has indulged in hatreds, suspicions, jealousies, and chauvinistic insolence. America
is not free from this charge.
. Armaments are one of the leading causes of war,
and the President's demand is a step along that road.
Instead of such a policy, our State Department would
do well to take a more common sensical direction toward the same goal. By aligning ourselves in a solid
front with our sister democracies against the predatory
states, by working slowly toward all possible disarmament, and by agitating for government control of
munitions, our statesmen would better further the cause
of peace.
Any immediate disarmament would be too drastic a
step. However, we should refuse any increase in arms
as the only way to eventual peace. We must resist the
pressure of war hysteria, the schernings of the gun
peddlers, and the intimidations of the vested interests.
We must stand by mankind's frail dream of peace!

The Johns Hopkins Musical Club,
the oldest of the Campus Activities.
was first organized as a Glee Club in
1833. With the growth of the University enrollment, the Musical Club has
remained the largest extra-curricula:
activity; its membership is now approximately one hundred men, embracing the Glee Club, the Banjo
Club, the Hawaiian Troupe and the
Blue Jay Orchestra, as well as smaller groups and soloiets.

Ingham Of News-Letter Is
Official Representative
— •
Giver 1200 amateur journalists
were drawn to New York City from
Eastern colleges and institutions for
the New York Times Christmas Conference on December 28. John Higham, '41, reporter and editorial writer
for the NEWS-LETTER, was official
Hopkins representative.
The Conference, an all-day affair
held in the Hotel Biltmore, featured
speakers on newspaper work and international affairs. In the morning
eleven editors, feature writers, and
executives of the Times addressed the
gathering on aspects of practical
journalism.
The afternoon was devoted to in,.etiational relations. Dr. Charles G.
Fe nwick, Professor
of Political
Science at Bryn Mawr College, spoke
on 'Neutrality and International
Responsibility". Dr. Fenwick received his Ph. D. at Hopkins.
The conference was concluded with
a trip through the Times plant in the
evening.
